author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Brittney Griner Announces Birth of Her Son
description: Less than two years after her release from a Russian penal colony, the W.N.B.A. center and two-time Olympic gold medal winner said that her son was born on July 8.
content: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. center and two-time Olympic gold medal winner, announced on Friday that she and her wife, Cherelle Griner, have welcomed their first child, less than two years after the basketball star was released from a penal colony in Russia and made her return to the sport for the Phoenix Mercury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders and Emmett Lindner
title: How to Guard Against Scams Tied to the CrowdStrike Crash
description: People posing as airline customer service representatives may be making fraudulent attempts to access your money or private data, experts warn.
content: In the hours after the American cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike deployed a flawed software update that crippled critical businesses and services around the world, scammers pounced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Republican Party Has a Split-Personality Problem
description: The people who would make Trump president want different things from him.
content: There is a paradox at the heart of Donald Trump’s campaign, a potentially irreconcilable divide that could damage his potential new presidency right from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Much Is Still Unknown as Listeria Again Takes Canadian Lives
description: While a listeria contamination of 18 nondairy milk alternatives has killed two people and sickened 10 more, Danone seems to be concealing a key fact.
content: When it was announced this week that two people had died from listeriosis after consuming plant-based milk alternatives sold by the French food giant Danone, I immediately thought of the listeria outbreak that peaked during 2008, in which cold cuts made by Maple Leaf Foods killed 22 people in one of Canada’s worst food safety disasters in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daron Acemoglu and James A. Robinson
title: Our Solution to the Crisis of Democracy
description: Center-left parties must lead the way to restore the social contract the binds democracies together.
content: Remember the 1990s, when everybody thought liberal democracy was the only game in town and the end of history was upon us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: I Watched the Republican Convention. The Democrats Can Still Win.
description: Ezra Klein discusses the anti-system populism on display at the 2024 G.O.P. convention — and what this might mean for the Democrats.
content: This year’s Republican National Convention was Donald Trump’s third as the party’s nominee, but it was the first that felt like a full expression of a G.O.P. that has fully fallen in line with Trumpism. And the mood was jubilant. Speakers even made efforts to reach out to unions, Black voters and immigrants — imagining a big-tent Republican Party that could be far more formidable at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
title: Wall Street’s Masters of the Universe Are Masters of None in 2024 Race
description: The financial world’s heavy hitters fear being marginalized in Washington after former President Trump chose a running mate openly hostile to Wall Street.
content: It’s a bad time to be a finance billionaire. Well, in Washington, D.C., anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: The Jewelry Shiona Turini Never Takes Off
description: The costume designer of “Lady in the Lake” and a stylist of looks for Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” understands the value of jewelry people wear every day.
content: Somewhere at the bottom of the North Atlantic Ocean, in the middle of the Bermuda Triangle, is one of four gold bracelets, gifted to Shiona Turini by her mother. She lost it while diving into the water from a cliff. A friend helped her search underwater for it with no luck. But this hasn’t deterred Ms. Turini from wearing most of her personal jewelry at all times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: To Deter Day-Trippers, Venice Tested a €5 Entrance Fee. Did Visitors Stay Away?
description: The mayor said preliminary data suggested that the experiment was a success. But the program brought in far more money than predicted, which critics called proof of failure.
content: When Venice introduced a five euro entrance fee in April, officials said the aim was to dissuade day-trippers from visiting at peak times, in a bid to ease the pressure on beleaguered residents forced to share the fragile city’s limited space and public resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Frangipane
title: How the Head of Luna Park on Coney Island Spends His Sundays
description: Alessandro Zamperla, the president of the group that manages the park, makes time for espresso and snacks while keeping an eye on all the rides.
content: While growing up in Vicenza, Italy, and playing professional rugby, Alessandro Zamperla did not imagine he would have a role in New York history. But with a last name that has become synonymous with the amusement industry, his destiny was in motion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: In My Defense …
description: John Ewbank’s puzzle teaches us what not to do the next time we’re in an argument.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron, Michael Gold and Simon J. Levien
title: Trump and Vance campaign together in Michigan, while Harris raises money on Cape Cod. Here’s the latest.
description: In his first campaign rally since the attempt on his life, former President Donald J. Trump, joined by his new running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, repeatedly lashed out at Democrats, calling President Biden and his administration “stupid.”
content: In his first campaign rally since the attempt on his life, former President Donald J. Trump, joined by his new running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, repeatedly lashed out at Democrats, calling President Biden and his administration “stupid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Some Seniors Readily Step Back. Some Never Will.
description: Researchers are only beginning to understand why some people embrace retirement while others won’t even consider it.
content: Beth Bergmans liked working as a project manager for an online university based in Minnesota. “We are offering opportunities for people to advance in life — that brought some satisfaction,” she said. “And the people I work with are awesome.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Blinken Says Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Is ‘Inside the 10-Yard Line’
description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, was more cautious as both spoke ahead of next week’s visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, said on Friday that an agreement to free hostages held in Gaza and establish a cease-fire was close, as administration officials prepared for what they expected to be a tense visit to Washington next week by Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Death of Vietnam’s Top Leader Raises Questions of Succession
description: The country’s political workings are notably opaque, but for now the president, who was until recently minister of public security, is carrying out the duties of general secretary.
content: With the death Friday of Vietnam’s long-serving Communist Party general secretary, Nguyen Phu Trong, the country’s top leadership role has been left at least temporarily to President To Lam, who is best known for implementing a sweeping anticorruption drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Emily Flitter
title: Flight Delays and Cancellations Continue Saturday but in Lower Numbers
description: An estimated 3,400 flights to, from and within the United States were canceled on Friday because of a tech outage. That made it the worst day of the year for flight cancellations.
content: Airlines made progress toward containing the fallout from a tech outage that disrupted global travel on Friday, though some flight delays and cancellations extended into Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: At Least 12 Dead and Dozens Missing After Highway Collapse in China
description: It was the second such rain-related disaster in less than three months, as extreme weather challenges the country’s extensive network of newly built expressways.
content: At least a dozen people were killed and many more remained missing on Saturday after part of a highway bridge collapsed Friday night amid heavy rain in western China. It was the second deadly episode in the country in less than three months involving the failure of a stretch of highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Applying for Rental Apartments: Will It Hurt Your Credit Score?
description: It doesn’t hurt to visit a lot of potential rentals, but be choosy about where you submit an application.
content: Q: I have rented apartments in the Washington, D.C. area for the past 30 years. I plan to move to New England, but before I buy a house, I want to rent for a while to experience a northern winter. I have a pretty good credit score, but I’m worried about what will happen when I apply for rental housing and the landlords do a credit check. When I purchased my first car a few years ago, seeking partial financing, the dealership sent inquiries to nine places, and my credit score plunged over 130 points. I’ve worked hard to build it back up but am worried about going through that again. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: At Least 2 Dead in Listeria Outbreak Tied to Deli-Sliced Meat
description: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said 28 people had been hospitalized with listeria infections across a dozen states.
content: At least two people have died and more than two dozen others have been sickened in an outbreak of listeria that appears to be connected to meat sliced at delis, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes
title: The Olympics Is Transforming Their Neighborhood. And Kicking Them Out.
description: The Games brought billions to redevelop this Paris suburb. What will the thousands of homeless people who live there do?
content: The building, once a warehouse, apartments and offices, is a temporary home — with one shower — for 60 adults and children. On the ground floor, rats sprint under plastic chairs and parked baby strollers. The stench of damp clothes and clogged toilets overpowers the strong scents of tomato and spices from the makeshift kitchenettes on upper floors. In the inner courtyard, laughter echoes as children scoop up giggling babies and gently swing them skyward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,127, Sunday, July 21, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Bridal Hats Are Making a Stylish Comeback
description: Fashion experts cite the influence of the British royals, along with high-profile events like the Kentucky Derby for the resurgence of this vintage wedding trend.
content: When Rose Minutaglio and Chris Marazzo stepped into Tiro a Segno, an Italian social club in New York, for their rehearsal dinner last winter, family and friends who were waiting there erupted in cheers. The enthusiastic response seemed to be not just for the couple, but also the customized, ivory-colored felt top hat worn by the bride-to-be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Magic Words
description: Ricky J. Sirois’s themeless puzzle tests our core strength.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — A new weekend constructor, cute animals, nostalgic pop culture: This puzzle is cozy, isn’t it? And then there’s that northwest corner. There are just so many places to go wrong. My solve came to a screeching halt and went in reverse for what felt like miles, until I unraveled my misdirects. But the three entries stacked across at the top made the intellectual effort worth it. They sparkle together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and J. David Goodman
title: Amid Talk of Border Chaos, Crossings Have Sharply Declined
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and the Texas governor are calling for a “secure border.” But actions by Mexico and President Biden have led to a period of relative calm.
content: The soaring number of unlawful entries at the southern border was always going be a central part of the 2024 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: ‘Twisters’ and the Appeal of the Sequel
description: When a sequel comes out, it can be an occasion to reaffirm why you love the original.
content: It recently came to my attention that several people I count as good friends have been engaged for decades in quietly impassioned romances with the same 1996 summer disaster movie. That movie is “Twister,” the story of a lovably eclectic band of tornado chasers who follow soon-to-be-divorced Bill Paxton and Helen Hunt right into the eye of many storms. It featured a 29-year-old Philip Seymour Hoffman, a storm-tracking device named “Dorothy” and a flying bovine, the sight of which inspires one character to get off the phone with the line: “I gotta go, Julia. We got cows.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: It’s Hot Out. People Still Look Good.
description: New Yorkers have found plenty of ways to navigate heat waves in style.
content: Summer heat waves are oppressive and can make it hard to get dressed in even the most basic garments. But scorching temperatures in June and July haven’t stopped New Yorkers from choosing chic attire over simple staples. Many people on the streets have found ways to keep cool without sacrificing their overall style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman and Mark Walker
title: Gunman at Trump Rally Had Drone in Car, Possibly to Scope Out the Site
description: Investigators have information that suggests a man intent on assassinating former President Donald J. Trump flew the device over the campaign event location on the day of the shooting.
content: Investigators found a small drone in the car owned by the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump — and believe it was used to survey the site of Mr. Trump’s rally in Butler, Pa., at least once before the shooting, according to law enforcement officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld and Kate Conger
title: When Tech Fails, It Is Usually With a Whimper Instead of a Bang
description: While in some corners of Silicon Valley people worry about the risks of A.I., a simple failed software update caused a worldwide outage.
content: For a couple of years now, the artificial intelligence community has been warning that there is a chance their work will go south and humanity will end in a conflagration worthy of a superhero movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Lord Almighty, Joe, Let It Go!
description: It’s sad that the president doesn’t see what’s inescapable.
content: Everyone wants Joe Biden gone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Debriefs the 2024 Republican National Convention
description: The July 20, 2024 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode debriefing the 2024 Republican National Convention with Claire Gordon. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The Voting Machine Conspiracy Theorists Are Still at It
description: Patrick Byrne, Mike Lindell and other Trump supporters who made baseless assertions that Dominion Voting Systems rigged the 2020 election are using court cases to keep spreading lies about the company.
content: Nearly four years later, zealous supporters of former President Donald J. Trump who promoted the conspiracy theory that Dominion Voting Systems had rigged its machines to rob him of the 2020 election are still at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: Leslie Uggams, a Fan of Both Nat King Cole and Billie Eilish
description: The actress, nominated for an Emmy and Golden Globe for her performance in “Roots,” is still going strong with appearances in the TV series “Fallout” and the upcoming movie “Deadpool & Wolverine.”
content: The veteran singer and actress Leslie Uggams likes to be busy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: 4 People, Including 2 Children, Are Found Dead in Brooklyn Apartment
description: At least one person, a 56-year-old woman, was found with multiple stab wounds in her neck. A man was in custody, the police said.
content: Four people, including a mother and her two young children, were found dead inside a Brooklyn apartment on Friday night after the police said they responded to reports of an assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Beth Gahan and Kate Selig
title: After Fire Destroys Sanctuary, Landmark Dallas Church Mourns What’s Lost
description: As officials work to determine the cause, many lament the damage at First Baptist Dallas, a church that grew along with the downtown around it.
content: The red brick outer walls of First Baptist Dallas Church were singed black on Saturday morning, and though they were still intact, along with the steeple at the front of the historic building, there was no sanctuary within. The roof, windows and interior were gone. And the smell of smoke lingered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Who’s Smiling Now? Nirvana and Marc Jacobs Settle Logo Lawsuit.
description: The rock band Nirvana sued the fashion line after it announced a “Bootleg Redux Grunge” collection in 2018.
content: Oh, that lawsuit Nirvana filed against the fashion line Marc Jacobs for using its smiley face logo without permission?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Campaign Prepares Attack Plan for Harris in Case Biden Withdraws
description: The effort, which includes expansive advertising and polling, assumes that the vice president would be the most likely candidate to replace the president at the top of the Democratic ticket.
content: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is preparing a major effort to attack Vice President Kamala Harris if President Biden steps aside as the Democratic nominee, including a wave of ads focusing on her record in her current office and in California, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Big Rethink
description: What happens when an event changes the way we see the people who are most important to us.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Los Angeles Novels as Stylish and Wild as the City Itself
description: Elizabeth Stromme’s noir about a writer for hire; Karen Tei Yamashita’s magic realist dystopia.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Lind
title: Trump’s Transformation of the Republican Party Is Complete
description: With JD Vance at his back, the former president has cemented his legacy.
content: Can Trumpism outlast Donald Trump? The selection of Senator JD Vance of Ohio as his running mate suggests that the answer is yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Here’s the Hope if Biden Withdraws
description: The assassination attempt, like so much else, should be a wake-up call. It was a near miss for Trump but also for America — and a chance to make things better.
content: An assassination attempt. An official Republican presidential nominee who is also the most polarizing figure in modern American history. Growing talk that Donald Trump could win in a landslide. His anointing of an heir to realign the parties and sustain Trumpism for years to come. And in the middle of it all, tormented by polls and criticism, able to change the entire dynamic only by sacrificing himself: Biden Agonistes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Christian Conservatives March Ahead for God, for Country, and for Trump
description: Donald Trump’s followers see more than a man divinely saved from a bullet. They see the rescue of a nation.
content: One after another, for four days, the testimonies for Donald J. Trump poured out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: How the U.S. Has Played a Role in Venezuela’s Presidential Election
description: The Biden administration helped prod the Venezuelan government to hold elections on July 28. Now, it is watching to see if the vote will be free and fair.
content: Venezuelans will head to the polls on July 28 to choose a new president, an election that could determine if democracy will be restored to the South American nation. It is also a vote that the United States played a role in helping ensure would take place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Zarroli
title: Motels Are Having a Moment
description: What’s old is new again, and the humble roadside motel that an older generation might dismiss as outmoded is appealing to a new group of younger fans attracted to hit-the-road adventures.
content: In 2022, Lisa Lennox was visiting a friend in Stephenville, Texas, when she stumbled upon the Interstate Inn. The motel, on a highway an hour west of Fort Worth, had seen better days. The building was notorious with the local police, and rooms rented for $40 a night. The property needed new plumbing and wiring, and asbestos had to be removed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Pena
title: Biden’s Executive Order Forces Migrants to Rethink Routes to U.S.
description: In Tapachula, Mexico, human smugglers are profiting off migrants heading north to the United States following President Biden’s executive order suspending and limiting asylum requests.
content: President Biden’s executive order last month that temporarily suspended asylum claims has forced migrants heading to the United States through Mexico to rethink and ultimately reroute their journeys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
title: Did Police in Kenya Catch a Serial Killer or Coerce a Confession?
description: After at least 10 sacks with body parts were found in a dump, a suspect was said to admit to 42 murders. But some doubt the case, and people with missing loved ones say the police were slow to help.
content: A 26-year-old hair braider named Josephine Owino disappeared one morning last month in the sprawling shantytown of Mukuru Kwa Njenga in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, after going out suddenly to see someone who had just phoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Noah Weiland
title: Is Bird Flu Spreading Widely to Farm Workers? A Small Study Offers Some Reassurance
description: Officials found no evidence of silent infections in 35 Michigan dairy workers, but experts noted that much more data was necessary.
content: Since an unusual bird flu outbreak was first detected in dairy cows in March, experts have warned that the virus could be infecting more farm workers than have been officially detected. Testing has been severely limited, constraining what health officials know about the ways that the virus is spreading from sick cows and contaminated equipment and how often it is spilling over into humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Indian Americans Become a Political Force, Just as Usha Vance’s Profile Rises
description: Indian Americans are now the largest and most politically active group among Asian Americans. Among their recent milestones: Vice President Kamala Harris, two G.O.P. presidential candidates — and a possible second lady.
content: When Senator JD Vance became Donald J. Trump’s running mate this week on the Republican presidential ticket, it also marked the first time that an Indian American and practicing Hindu, Usha Vance, stood to become a vice-presidential spouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Thomas Neff, Who Turned Soviet Warheads Into Electricity, Dies at 80
description: An M.I.T. physicist, he engineered an East-West deal that reduced nuclear threats and produced one of the greatest peace dividends of all time.
content: As the Soviet Union disintegrated, Thomas L. Neff came up with an improbable idea. What if Soviet nuclear warheads could light up American cities rather than obliterate them? What if the United States could buy the uranium cores of the deadly arms and turn them into reactor fuel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By S. Kirk Walsh
title: A 17th-Century Parisian Literary Salon Rife With Stories and Sex
description: Clare Pollard’s novel “The Modern Fairies” reanimates 25 classic tales through a contemporary lens.
content: In her sophomore novel, “The Modern Fairies,” the British writer Clare Pollard cleverly animates the art of storytelling and its roots in French history. In the late 17th century, during the ruthless reign of Louis XIV, an eclectic group of Parisian intellectuals met frequently in a literary salon on the Rue St.-Benoit run by a divorced writer, Madame d’Aulnoy, to tell one another fairy tales. This gathering of mostly noblewomen and a handful of men made up an unofficial literary institution that established a new genre of literature. More than a century later, some of these oral fables — or “Mother Goose tales” — evolved into the Brothers Grimm classics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Orecchiette Salad With Halloumi Croutons
description: Crispy, golden, squeaky-centered halloumi croutons.
content: A thesis (and potentially unpopular opinion): Pasta salad is at its best when the salad element is kept at arm’s length. I do not eat pasta salad for lettuce or spinach or other leafy greens, I eat pasta salad for, well, pasta. And I want the pasta to be those wacky shapes I would never let near my long-simmered Sunday Bolognese: fusilli, farfalle, elbow macaroni, orzo. I believe the pasta salad apotheosis is Hawaii’s mac salad, where the noodle is squat and curled and the vegetable element is one grated carrot in a metric ton of mayonnaise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Ex-Marine Sentenced to Nearly 5 Years for Role in Jan. 6 Riot
description: Tyler Bradley Dykes was charged with assaulting law enforcement after prosecutors said he stole a police officer’s riot shield to help break into the Capitol.
content: A South Carolina man who was serving in the United States Marine Corps when he stormed the United States Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and stole a police officer’s riot shield to help break into the building was sentenced on Friday to nearly five years in prison, according to federal prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Derek M. Norman
title: Airlines and Passengers Still Struggling, a Day After Global Outage
description: The widespread tech failure left carriers trying to recover and passengers waiting for relief, with many flights still delayed or canceled.
content: A day after a tech outage disrupted industries worldwide, airlines are digging themselves out from the fallout of thousands of delayed and canceled flights that have left travelers stranded and searching to find a way home over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: An Egyptian Artist Mesmerizes in Venice With an Opera and a Donkey
description: At the Biennale, Wael Shawky represented his country with a lush retelling of a failed revolution that offers hope in a troubled political landscape.
content: If you think a filmed opera sung entirely in classical Arabic that tells, in detail, the complex story of a relatively obscure, failed 19th-century uprising in Egypt might be something less than compelling, do I have news for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Kate Kelly, Jeanna Smialek and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Dozens of Local Police Officers Were at Trump’s Rally. Very Few Were Watching a Critical Area.
description: Local law enforcement officials, present in abundance, said they were not assigned security duties around a warehouse used by a man who tried to kill former President Donald Trump.
content: A key question after an assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump a week ago is why the Secret Service excluded from its secured zone a nearby warehouse the gunman used for his assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Gessen
title: The Seeds of This Political Disaster Were Sown Decades Ago
description: We are living in a realm in which “nothing is true and everything is possible.”
content: Four years ago the Republican convention was a bizarre spectacle, a cross between a Napoleonic fantasy and a Leni Riefenstahl movie. The dominant image was of an imperial dynasty laying claim to forever rule. I expected more of the same when I tuned in on Monday night to watch this year’s convention, but amped up even further by the weekend’s terrifying near-miss assassination attempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: How Americans Justify Political Violence
description: Partisan support for the killing of adversaries is much more widespread than anyone wants to admit.
content: In August 2022, I attended a gathering of right-wing grassroots organizations at a horse-show complex in Bloomsburg, Pa., a few hours’ drive east of where Donald Trump survived an assassination attempt last weekend. Everyone who went up to speak believed the 2020 election had been stolen from Trump, and now they were discussing what to do about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Keith Collins, Edgar Sandoval and Jeremy White
title: Bus by Bus, Texas’ Governor Changed Migration Across the U.S.
description: In two years, Texas has bused more than 119,000 people to Democrat-led cities, shifting both migration patterns and the debate over immigration. The list of cities keeps expanding.
content: The autumn of 2021 delivered a shock to the state of Texas. More than 9,000 migrants crossed the border on a September day into the town of Del Rio and huddled in a tent camp under a bridge. Thousands more came later that week from countries all over the world, challenging the town’s ability to handle them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Trump and Zelensky Speak by Phone as Ukraine Worries About U.S. Backing
description: Kyiv ponders what another Trump administration would mean for its war initiatives.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, spoke over the phone late this week amid mounting concern in Kyiv that a second Trump administration would spell the end of American support in Ukraine’s fight against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: The Buried Book That Helped Ukraine’s Literary Revival
description: To keep it from Russian forces, a writer hid his last manuscript under a cherry tree. Its rediscovery became part of a flowering of interest in Ukrainian literature.
content: After Russian forces took control of his village in 2022, Volodymyr Vakulenko, a well-known Ukrainian author, sensed he might soon be arrested. So he buried his new handwritten manuscript in his backyard, under a cherry tree.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Investing in Pediatric Care
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about the shortage of pediatricians and what to do about it.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Adler-Bell
title: Why Is Autocracy Thriving? Anne Applebaum Says: It’s the Economy, Stupid.
description: In “Autocracy, Inc.,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian takes account of the financial institutions and trade deals that have helped spread tyranny across the world.
content: Something new is happening in the world of oppression. Or so says the historian Anne Applebaum. Whereas the twilight struggle of the 20th century was waged between formal “blocs” of ideologically aligned allies, today’s autocrats are more diverse — a mix of self-described Marxists, illiberal demagogues, kleptocratic mafiosi, old-school tyrants and new-school theocrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Robert Jimison
title: Pelosi Told Colleagues She Would Favor ‘Open’ Nomination Process if Biden Drops Out
description: The former House speaker and fellow California lawmakers were discussing the Democratic Party’s stressful state of affairs.
content: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the former speaker, recently told her colleagues in the California delegation that if President Biden were to end his campaign she would favor the “competitive” process of an open primary rather than an anointment of Vice President Kamala Harris as the new Democratic presidential nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Shuaib Almosawa and Eric Schmitt
title: Israeli Jets Bomb Sites in Yemen Linked to Iran-Backed Houthis
description: The strike was retaliation for a drone attack launched from Yemen a day earlier, which evaded Israel’s defenses and hit a building in Tel Aviv, killing one person.
content: Israeli fighter jets bombed a port in Yemen controlled by the Iran-backed Houthi militia on Saturday in retaliation for the group’s deadly drone attack in Tel Aviv a day earlier. It was the first time Israel has publicly struck the group following months of escalating Houthi attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Psychologist Who Waterboarded C.I.A. Prisoners Defends Method’s Use in 9/11 Case
description: The man accused of planning the attacks was waterboarded 183 times. The now outlawed “enhanced interrogation” technique is considered a form of torture.
content: In the years after the C.I.A. waterboarded the man accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, the agency offered explanations of how he withstood the technique 183 times at a secret overseas prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: In These 3 Novels, Power Struggles in Every Era
description: Immerse yourself in tales of Machiavellian statecraft, Depression-era scandal and emotional turmoil on an R.A.F. air base.
content: “You now understand what power truly is. The discovery has spread through you like poison.” Years later, the ruthless warlord Cesare Borgia’s remark will cast its shadow over Niccolò Machiavelli’s notorious 16th-century political treatise, “The Prince.” At least that’s the impression you get from Franco Bernini’s engrossing novel, THE THRONE (Europa, 416 pp., $30), translated from the Italian by Oonagh Stransky. It’s just the first in a projected trilogy set in an era whose notions of statecraft can seem even more rapacious than our own.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Poet Who Commands a Rebel Army
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 20, 2024.
content: “Words are powerful weapons. But against the military, we need real weapons because they don’t fight fairly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Is This the Summer of the Kamala Harris Coconut Meme?
description: As the vice president’s name is floated as a potential presidential candidate, the internet took a goofy joke and ran with it — all the way to the bar.
content: President Biden said he would no longer seek re-election and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris. Follow live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: From the Playing Field to Wall Street
description: For more than 200 pro athletes, the boutique investment firm Patricof Co is opening the door to the private equity market.
content: In Orchard Park, N.Y., this past January, just as the tight end Travis Kelce caught a touchdown pass to help the Kansas City Chiefs take the lead in a playoff game against the Buffalo Bills, the real action for many fans watching at home was high above the field. There, in a crowded luxury box, Mr. Kelce’s brother, the burly Philadelphia Eagle offensive lineman, Jason Kelce, was dancing shirtless and chugging from a beer, as Travis’s girlfriend, Taylor Swift, looked on in a combination of amusement and astonishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Michael J. de la Merced and Sarah Kessler
title: Why Some of the Loudest Cheers for Trump Are Coming From Silicon Valley
description: Elon Musk, David Sacks, Marc Andreessen and other influential figures in technology have endorsed former President Donald Trump.
content: How did the Democrats lose Silicon Valley? Or did they?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, Champion for Progressive Causes, Dies at 74
description: A Democrat from the Houston area, she led the effort to make Juneteenth a federal holiday.
content: Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a Democrat from Texas who was a leading voice for racial justice and progressive causes during three decades in the House, died on Friday in Houston. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Before the Alec Baldwin Trial’s End, 2 Jurors Had Doubts About His Guilt
description: When the judge threw out the case, the jurors said, they had doubts that Mr. Baldwin was guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the fatal shooting of the cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust.”
content: When the judge threw out the involuntary manslaughter case against Alec Baldwin earlier this month after finding that the prosecution had withheld evidence that could have helped his defense, it left key questions that have hung over the case for more than two years unresolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Fund to Aid Children Harmed at Birth Hasn’t Kept Promises, Families Say
description: The Medical Indemnity Fund was to provide worry-free health care to children severely injured at birth. But parents say it has failed them.
content: The birth had been long and difficult. Denise Olivio requested a cesarean section, she said, but was rebuffed until a doctor decided it was an emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Divisive Far-Right Politician in Ukraine Is Fatally Shot
description: Iryna Farion, a former lawmaker, was known for controversial campaigns to discredit Russian-speaking Ukrainians.
content: A gunman shot and killed a far-right Ukrainian politician who stirred controversy with campaigns to promote the Ukrainian language and discredit Russian-speaking compatriots, the authorities say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: An ‘Awful Event’ for the United States, and an Editor
description: The assassination of Abraham Lincoln shook the nation. But it was the concurrent attack on the secretary of state that also shook the founder of The New York Times, who considered him a political exemplar.
content: The assassination of President Abraham Lincoln by John Wilkes Booth on April 14, 1865, was an awful event for the United States. But it was truly awful for Henry Jarvis Raymond (1820-1869), the founding editor of The New York Times, a supporter, confidant and biographer of Lincoln whom the president once called “my lieutenant general in politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders and Ruth Graham
title: Fire Badly Damages Sanctuary of a Landmark Church in Dallas
description: The roof of a 19th-century part of the First Baptist Dallas Church in the city’s downtown appeared to have collapsed.
content: A fire that broke out Friday at the First Baptist Dallas church, a landmark in the city’s downtown, appeared to cause major damage to an old part of the church complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Joel Embiid Believes He Could Have Been the GOAT
description: The N.B.A. star talks Philly cheesesteaks, Twitter trolling and playing for Team U.S.A. over France in the Olympics.
content: If all goes according to plan, the star-laden American men’s basketball team will romp to a gold medal at the Paris Olympic Games next month. Which means that for one of the team’s linchpins, the Philadelphia 76ers star Joel Embiid, the most complicated challenge may have been choosing to play for the United States in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Houthi Drone Strike Highlights Dilemmas for Israel
description: Israel has few options to retaliate for the attack in Tel Aviv, which made clear the weakness of its air defense system against unmanned aircraft and heightened concerns about the threat of Iranian-backed militias.
content: Israel faces a strategic dilemma over how best to retaliate for the drone attack on Tel Aviv claimed by Yemen’s Houthi militia, which is based thousands of miles from Israel’s southern borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 406, July 21, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: What Happened to Digital Resilience?
description: With each cascade of digital disaster, new vulnerabilities emerge. The latest chaos wasn’t caused by an adversary, but it provided a road map of American vulnerabilities at a critical moment.
content: In the worst-case scenarios that the Biden administration has quietly simulated over the past year or so, Russian hackers working on behalf of Vladimir V. Putin bring down hospital systems across the United States. In others, China’s military hackers trigger chaos, shutting down water systems and electric grids to distract Americans from an invasion of Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 20, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 20, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about issues with cord blood banks misspelled the first name of a former sales representative for CBR. She is Stacey Seaver, not Stacy Seaver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Trump Sabotaged His Own Apotheosis
description: Having Trump as a dominant figure keeps American politics in a state of unsettlement.
content: The six days that carried Donald Trump from the stage in Butler, Pa., to the rostrum at the Republican National Convention seemed at times like the buildup to a moment of total political domination, an apotheosis for the Republican nominee and confusion and defeat for his opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
title: Bangladesh Orders Curfew in Effort to Quell Deadly Unrest
description: For weeks, university students have been protesting a quota system for government jobs. Suppression led to a cycle of violence and now a paralyzing curfew.
content: The authorities in Bangladesh have ordered a nationwide curfew and deployed the army as clashes between student-led protesters and the police and paramilitary forces have killed dozens of people and brought Dhaka, the nation’s capital, to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Running the Packers Is Complicated. A Sense of Humor Helps.
description: In the N.F.L., being the chief executive of a publicly owned, nonprofit franchise is a singular job. Mark Murphy has been doing it for 17 years.
content: On a sunny summer day two years ago, Mark Murphy hosted one of the most unusual events in corporate America: the Green Bay Packers’ annual meeting. Thousands of the team’s shareholders — almost all of them fans who had paid hundreds of dollars for nearly worthless shares — filled Lambeau Field and listened to Murphy, the team’s president and chief executive officer, provide updates on the state of the franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Braveheart,’ ‘Grandpa,’ ‘Trumpster’: MAGA in 7 Keywords
description: A partial lexicon of modern Republicanism.
content: The purpose of an American political convention, at least the parts broadcast to the public, is to find a universal language that will advance a particular ideology. In that respect, many of the speeches in Milwaukee this week sounded, well, conventional. Controversial positions having to do with economics, immigration, abortion and the law were wrapped in concepts that nobody could possibly oppose: freedom, security, hard work, unity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Meet the Flip-Flop Club: 7 Republicans Who Kissed the Ring
description: How Donald Trump’s former critics turned from denunciations to praise at the Republican convention.
content: How Donald Trump’s former critics turned from denunciations to praise at the Republican convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris and Larry Buchanan
title: Test Your Focus: Can You Spend 10 Minutes With One Painting?
description: It’s very hard to slow down and look closely at something. You may find it’s worth it.
content: It’s very hard to slow down and look closely at something. You may find it’s worth it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Claire Hogan, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Laura Salaberry and Rebecca Suner
title: Elon Musk Is a Critical but Shaky Republican Donor
description: Elon Musk has undergone a midlife reinvention that has many Republicans salivating about him as the party’s moneymaker — if he delivers. Theodore Schleifer, a New York Times reporter who covers campaign finance and the influence of the ultrawealthy in American politics, explains.
content: Elon Musk has undergone a midlife reinvention that has many Republicans salivating about him as the party’s moneymaker — if he delivers. Theodore Schleifer, a New York Times reporter who covers campaign finance and the influence of the ultrawealthy in American politics, explains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Pena, Benjamin Alfaro and Amy Marino
title: ‘There’s No Way to Turn Yourself In’: Migrants Rethink Routes to U.S.
description: In Tapachula, Mexico, migrants en route to the United States are being forced to reroute their journeys after President Biden’s executive order suspending and limiting asylum requests, and human smugglers are profiting.
content: In Tapachula, Mexico, migrants en route to the United States are being forced to reroute their journeys after President Biden’s executive order suspending and limiting asylum requests, and human smugglers are profiting.
source.name: The New York Times
